title: Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus
scope: ** Comprehensive evaluation of suspected NPH, diagnostic workup including high-volume lumbar puncture (tap test), prediction of shunt responsiveness, neurosurgical referral, and post-shunt monitoring. Covers idiopathic NPH (most common) and secondary NPH. Does not cover acute obstructive hydrocephalus or pediatric hydrocephalus.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Pre-procedural assessment for LP and surgery
B12 deficiency causes reversible dementia and gait ataxia
Rule out UTI as cause of incontinence or confusion
Diabetes contributes to small vessel disease and neuropathy

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Neurosyphilis can cause dementia and gait abnormalities
HIV-associated neurocognitive disorder in at-risk patients
Inflammatory or infectious causes of meningitis/encephalitis
Hepatic encephalopathy in patients with liver disease
Prostate disease contributing to urinary symptoms

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.item: Genetic testing for APP, PSEN1, PSEN2 (81405)

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Confirm normal or mildly elevated pressure in NPH
Lumbar Puncture.target: 5-18 cm H2O (typically normal or low-normal in NPH)
Normal in NPH; low Abeta-42 with high tau in AD

Essential/First-line.target: Ventriculomegaly with Evans index >0.3; callosal angle <90 degrees; DESH pattern; periventricular edema (transependymal flow); absence of cortical atrophy proportionate to ventricular size

Essential/First-line.timing: If MRI unavailable or emergent presentation
Essential/First-line.target: Ventriculomegaly out of proportion to sulcal enlargement; Evans index >0.3

Extended.target: Quantify ventricular volume; hippocampal volume preservation (unlike AD); tight high-convexity sulci

Extended.item: MRI with CSF flow study - phase-contrast (70553)
Extended.target: Hyperdynamic aqueductal flow; increased stroke volume (>42 microL)

Extended.timing: Atypical cases to differentiate from AD
Extended.target: Normal NAA/Cr ratio (reduced in AD); no significant metabolic abnormality

Extended.timing: Differentiate NPH from AD or FTD

Rare/Specialized.target: Elevated Rout >12-18 mmHg/mL/min suggests shunt responsiveness

Rare/Specialized.timing: Rarely used; assesses CSF flow patterns
Rare/Specialized.target: Delayed clearance over convexities; ventricular reflux

Acute/Emergent.indication: Temporizing measure while awaiting surgery; reduces CSF production

dosing.instructions: Start 250 mg BID; titrate to 250 mg TID or 500 mg BID; max 2 g/day

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Sulfa allergy; severe hepatic/renal disease; hypokalemia; metabolic acidosis

Acute/Emergent.indication: Temporizing measure; confirm continued benefit; bridge to surgery

dosing.instructions: Remove 30-50 mL every 1-4 weeks based on symptom recurrence

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Cognitive symptoms; may provide modest benefit pending surgery

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg daily; increase by 5 mg/week; target 10 mg BID

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Severe renal impairment (adjust dose if CrCl <30)

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Cognitive symptoms if AD component suspected

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg qHS x 4-6 weeks; increase to 10 mg qHS

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Sick sinus syndrome; GI bleeding; COPD

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg BID; may increase to 5 mg TID; or use ER 10-30 mg daily

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Uncontrolled narrow-angle glaucoma; urinary retention; GI obstruction

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Urinary urgency if anticholinergics contraindicated or cause cognitive worsening

dosing.instructions: Start 25 mg daily; may increase to 50 mg daily
Start 0.4 mg daily; may increase to 0.8 mg daily
Start 25-50 mg qHS; titrate to 50-150 mg qHS
Initial evaluation plus ongoing therapy for gait training, balance, strength

Definitive Treatment (Shunt Surgery).indication: Definitive treatment for NPH; positive tap test or extended drain trial

dosing.instructions: Valve pressure setting adjusted based on symptoms; typical starting setting 120-180 mmH2O

Definitive Treatment (Shunt Surgery).contraindications: Active peritoneal infection; peritoneal adhesions; recent abdominal surgery; ascites
Definitive Treatment (Shunt Surgery).monitoring: Post-op neuro checks; shunt series imaging; valve setting verification

Definitive Treatment (Shunt Surgery).indication: Alternative if peritoneum unsuitable (adhesions, peritonitis history)

dosing.instructions: Catheter tip in right atrium; valve adjusted as VP shunt

Definitive Treatment (Shunt Surgery).contraindications: Active bacteremia; severe cardiac disease; pulmonary hypertension
Definitive Treatment (Shunt Surgery).monitoring: Post-op neuro checks; shunt series imaging; valve setting verification; cardiac monitoring; watch for shunt nephritis

dosing.instructions: Catheter from lumbar subarachnoid space to peritoneum

Definitive Treatment (Shunt Surgery).monitoring: Post-op neuro checks; shunt series imaging; valve setting verification; watch for overdrainage with positional changes

dosing.instructions: Create opening between third ventricle and interpeduncular cistern

Definitive Treatment (Shunt Surgery).contraindications: Communicating hydrocephalus (most iNPH); scarred prepontine cistern

doseOptions.orderSentence: Valve pressure adjustment (overdrainage) Increase setting External programming

dosing.instructions: Increase opening pressure by 20-30 mmH2O increments; recheck in 1-2 weeks
dosing.orderSentence: Valve pressure adjustment (overdrainage) Increase setting External programming

doseOptions.orderSentence: Valve pressure adjustment (underdrainage) Decrease setting External programming

dosing.instructions: Decrease opening pressure by 20-30 mmH2O increments; recheck in 1-2 weeks
dosing.orderSentence: Valve pressure adjustment (underdrainage) Decrease setting External programming

dosing.instructions: 15-20 mg/kg IV q8-12h; adjust for renal function; target trough 15-20 mcg/mL
2 g IV q8h; adjust for renal function

doseOptions.orderSentence: Shunt revision surgery Per neurosurgery Surgical

dosing.instructions: Shunt externalization if infected; revision for mechanical failure
dosing.orderSentence: Shunt revision surgery Per neurosurgery Surgical

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology for comprehensive evaluation, differential diagnosis, and coordination of diagnostic workup
Neurosurgery for shunt candidacy evaluation after positive tap test or extended drain trial
Neuropsychology for baseline cognitive assessment and differentiation from other dementias (AD, vascular)
Physical therapy for gait assessment, fall prevention, and baseline measurement for tap test comparison
Occupational therapy for ADL assessment, home safety evaluation, and cognitive strategies
Urology for evaluation if urinary symptoms prominent or atypical for NPH
Social work for caregiver support, community resources, and care planning
Geriatrics or geriatric psychiatry for complex older patients with multiple comorbidities

Patient Instructions.item: Return immediately if sudden severe headache, new weakness, or altered consciousness develops (may indicate shunt malfunction or complication)
Report fever, incision redness, or drainage after shunt surgery (may indicate shunt infection)
Keep scheduled follow-up appointments for shunt valve pressure adjustments and monitoring
Use assistive devices (walker, cane) as recommended by physical therapy to prevent falls
Do not drive until cleared by physician due to cognitive impairment and fall risk
Avoid MRI without confirming shunt valve is MRI-conditional and checking valve setting afterward
Carry shunt information card with valve type and current pressure setting

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Fall precautions including removal of throw rugs, adequate lighting, grab bars in bathroom due to gait instability
Regular physical activity within safe limits to maintain strength and mobility
Cognitive stimulation through reading, puzzles, and social engagement to support cognitive reserve
Blood pressure optimization (target <130/80) to reduce vascular contribution to cognitive impairment
Adequate hydration to maintain optimal CSF dynamics; avoid dehydration
Bladder training program in conjunction with physical therapy for urinary symptoms

differential.features: Memory impairment predominant; insidious progression; no significant gait disturbance early; no improvement with LP
differential.tests: MRI shows hippocampal atrophy >ventricular enlargement; CSF low Abeta-42, high tau; no tap test response

differential.features: Stepwise decline; focal neurological signs; executive dysfunction; vascular risk factors
differential.tests: MRI shows extensive white matter disease, strategic infarcts; ventriculomegaly less prominent

differential.features: Rest tremor; rigidity; bradykinesia; shuffling gait differs from NPH magnetic gait; no incontinence early
differential.tests: DaTscan abnormal; no tap test response; no ventriculomegaly disproportionate to atrophy

differential.features: Visual hallucinations; fluctuating cognition; parkinsonism; REM sleep behavior disorder
differential.tests: DaTscan abnormal; no ventricular enlargement out of proportion to atrophy

differential.features: Vertical gaze palsy; postural instability with falls backward; axial rigidity
differential.tests: MRI midbrain atrophy ("hummingbird sign"); no tap test response

differential.features: Upper motor neuron signs in legs; hyperreflexia; Babinski; sensory level
differential.tests: Cervical MRI shows cord compression; EMG findings

differential.features: Sensory loss distally; reduced reflexes; no cognitive or urinary symptoms
Acute onset; headache; papilledema; elevated opening pressure on LP
differential.tests: MRI shows obstructive lesion; elevated ICP; requires emergent intervention

differential.features: Neurogenic claudication; leg pain with walking relieved by rest/leaning forward
differential.tests: Lumbar MRI shows stenosis; normal brain imaging

differential.features: Behavioral changes prominent; personality changes; language impairment
differential.tests: MRI frontal/temporal atrophy; FDG-PET frontal hypometabolism

evidence.recommendation: Callosal angle <90 degrees supports iNPH diagnosis
High-volume LP (tap test) predicts shunt response
Extended lumbar drainage more sensitive than single tap test
evidence.source: [Walchenbach et al. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 2002](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11909911/)

evidence.recommendation: VP shunt improves symptoms in selected iNPH patients
evidence.source: [Hebb et al. Can J Neurol Sci 2001](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11846911/)

evidence.recommendation: Programmable valves reduce revision surgery rates
Gait improvement most responsive to shunting
Short symptom duration predicts better shunt outcome
CSF biomarkers help differentiate NPH from AD
Shunt infection rate 5-10%; requires shunt removal for treatment

monitoring.action: Positive change supports diagnosis; no change may indicate poor shunt candidacy
Improvement suggests NPH; decline suggests alternative diagnosis or shunt failure
Repeat imaging if symptoms change; adjust valve

monitoring.frequency: After any MRI; at each clinic visit
monitoring.action: Reprogram if reset; ensure appropriate setting
Decline triggers workup for shunt malfunction or alternative diagnosis
Adjust valve pressure higher; surgical evacuation if large/symptomatic
Blood/CSF cultures; shunt tap; IV antibiotics; possible shunt removal
Adjust bladder medications; confirm NPH response

disposition.criteria: Stable symptoms; workup complete; awaiting outpatient tap test; caregiver support available
Extended lumbar drain trial; post-shunt observation; shunt complication evaluation
Acute shunt malfunction with altered mental status; symptomatic overdrainage with large subdural; shunt infection with sepsis
Neurology 2-4 weeks after tap test to review results; Neurosurgery evaluation if positive tap test; post-shunt follow-up at 1-3 months, 6 months, then annually
Positive tap test; positive extended drain trial; progressive symptoms with classic imaging findings
